qas.question: What year did Nintendo release the Famicom Disk System?
Where could the disks for the game be obtained?

answers.text: buyers could select a title and have it written to the disk

qas.question: What were the storage disks used for?

answers.text: storing the game and saving progress

qas.question: What was the total capacity of a disk?
What year did Atari release the Famicom Disk System?

plausible_answers.text: buyers could select a title and have it written to the disk
storing the game and saving progress

qas.question: What weren't the storage disks used for?
What was half of the total capacity of a disk?

context: In <a0_0><b5_0>1986<b5_0/><a0_0/>, Nintendo released the Famicom Disk System (FDS) in Japan, a type of floppy drive that uses a single-sided, proprietary 5 cm (2") disk and plugs into the cartridge port. It contains RAM for the game to load into and an extra single-cycle wavetable-lookup sound chip. The disks were originally obtained from <a1_0><b6_0>kiosks in malls<b6_0/><a1_0/> and other public places where <a2_0><b7_0>buyers could select a title and have it written to the disk<b7_0/><a2_0/>. This process would cost less than cartridges and users could take the disk back to a vending booth and have it rewritten with a new game. The disks were used both for <a3_0><b8_0>storing the game and saving progress<b8_0/><a3_0/> and total capacity was <a4_0><b9_0>128k<b9_0/><a4_0/> (64k per side).
